plant.description:
Brief Description
• Appearance: It is described as a shrub with simple, lanceolate (lance-shaped) leaves that have entire or slightly serrated margins. It features small, star-shaped white flowers. The plant produces red, shiny berries (ripe fruits) that contain many white seeds.
• Common Locations: It is commonly kept as a houseplant or ornamental shrub.• Houseplants and Ornamentals Toxic to Animals - Toxicology - Merck Veterinary Manual

toxins.name: Solanocapsine (and related alkaloids)
toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ Gastrointestinal Irritation: The alkaloids act as potent irritants to the gastrointestinal tract, capable of causing severe inflammation and hemorrhagic diarrhea (bloody stool).
    ◦ Systemic Neurological and Cardiac Effects: The toxins affect the central nervous system and heart, leading to progressive weakness, paralysis, and bradycardia (dangerously slow heart rate). In severe cases, this can escalate to circulatory collapse and convulsions.
4. Notes on
toxins.concentration_notes:
◦ Distribution: The toxic alkaloids are found in the leaves and the fruits (berries).
    ◦ Potency: Ingestion can cause a wide range of severe clinical signs, from gastrointestinal distress to fatal circulatory collapse.• Houseplants and Ornamentals Toxic to Animals - Toxicology - Merck Veterinary Manual

symptoms.name: Vomiting, Diarrhea (often Hemorrhagic), Abdominal Pain, Anorexia
symptoms.onset: 2–24 hours (General onset for Solanaceae/Nightshade alkaloid toxicity).
symptoms.notes: The diarrhea is specifically noted to be hemorrhagic (containing blood) in some cases. The irritation can also cause hypersalivation (drooling).Neurological Dysfunction (Seizures and Paralysis)

symptoms.name: Convulsions (Seizures), Progressive Weakness, Paralysis, Dilated Pupils
symptoms.onset: Delayed (Neurological signs often follow gastrointestinal distress as the toxin is absorbed).
symptoms.notes: The clinical picture includes progressive weakness that can escalate to paralysis and convulsions. The alkaloids affect the central nervous system significantly.Cardiovascular Collapse

symptoms.name: Bradycardia (Slow Heart Rate), Circulatory Collapse
symptoms.notes: The alkaloids can cause a dangerous slowing of the heart rate (bradycardia) leading to total circulatory collapse (shock).Respiratory Distress

symptoms.name: Dyspnea (Difficulty Breathing)
symptoms.notes: Respiratory paralysis or distress is a potential complication of the severe neurological depression caused by the toxin.

treatments.name: Gastric Lavage (Stomach Pumping)
treatments.description: The veterinarian inserts a tube into the cat's stomach to wash out contents and remove unabsorbed plant material.
treatments.notes: This is explicitly suggested to remove the toxic alkaloids from the system before they can be fully absorbed.Toxin Adsorption

treatments.name: Administration of Activated Charcoal
treatments.description: A substance is administered orally to bind with the remaining toxins in the gastrointestinal tract, preventing them from entering the bloodstream.
treatments.notes: This step typically follows decontamination to minimize the bioavailability of the ingested alkaloids.Supportive Therapy

treatments.name: Fluid and Electrolyte Therapy
treatments.description: Intravenous (IV) fluids and electrolytes are administered to correct dehydration and imbalances caused by severe vomiting and diarrhea.
treatments.notes: This treatment is crucial for managing circulatory collapse (shock) and hemorrhagic diarrhea, both of which are potential severe symptoms of Jerusalem Cherry poisoning.Neurological Management

treatments.name: Administration of Anticonvulsants
treatments.description: Medications are given to control or prevent seizures and convulsions.
treatments.notes: This is necessary if the cat exhibits severe neurological signs, such as convulsions, which are documented effects of the plant's toxins.
